prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
In this science goal, we will observe the 3(1,2)-2(2,1) and 2(1,1)-2(1,2) HDO transitions (225.9 and 241.6 GHz, Band 6). The peak line strengths were predicted by line radiative transfer modeling of the 1-D physical model of GSS30-IRS1 by Kristensen et al. (2012). The relative H2O abundance was taken to be 2E-04 in the inner warm (T>100 K) region and several orders of magnitude lower (~1E-08) in the outer parts. The HDO/H2O ratio was assumed to be 3E-4, comparable to what is seen in Earth's Oceans, and lower than found in Class 0 protostars and comets. While the peak flux was estimated with abundances derived in studies of Class~0 sources (i.e. 2E-04), the RMS was estimated from the same model, but assuming a conservative relative water abundance of 2E-05, thus even at this lower value the lines will be detected at a 3 sigma level for 1 km/s bins. Included in the setting is the J=2-1 line of C17O at 224.7 GHz that can put additional constraints on the kinematics. The continuum for the sources were estimated from Jorgensen et al. (2009) by assuming that the emission is evenly distributed over the region and a beam of 0.3 arcseconds. We will target the sources with a spectral resolution of ~0.08 km/s and smooth the data depending on the resulting intensity, and as mentioned above the lines will be detected even for a conservative estimate of the water abundance.
To map any spatial differences we need a resolution of 0.3 arcseconds attainable in Band 6 with C34-5, which corresponds to about R=20 AU at the distances of the sources. The outer radius of the warm inner region is expected to vary between 20 and 100 AU depending on the source parameters. The largest scale on which the water and HDO lines are predicted is at most a couple of hundred AU's, i.e. less than 2 arcseconds, whereas the largest recoverable scale is 6.3 arcseconds at these frequencies, therefore no compact array is needed and spatial filtering is not an issue.

In this science goal, we will observe the 4(1,4)-3(2,1) ortho-H2-18O transition at 390.6~GHz (Band~8). The peak line strengths were predicted by line radiative transfer modeling of the 1-D physical model of GSS30-IRS1 by Kristensen et al. (2012). The relative H2O abundance (o/p=3,16O/18O=550) was taken to be 2E-04 in the inner warm (T<100 K) region and several orders of magnitude lower (~1E-08) in the outer parts. While the peak flux was estimated with abundances derived in studies of Class~0 sources (i.e. 2E-04), the RMS was estimated a conservative relative water abundance of 2E-05, thus even at this lower value the lines will be detected at a 3 sigma level for 1 km/s bins. The continuum for the sources were estimated from Jorgensen et al. (2009) by assuming that the emission is evenly distributed over the region and a beam of 0.3 arcseconds. We will target the sources with a spectral resolution of ~0.09 km/s and smooth the data if necessary to improve the signal-to-noise, and as mentioned above the lines will be detected even for a conservative estimate of the water abundance.
To map any spatial differences we need a resolution of 0.3 arcseconds attainable in Band 8 with C34-5, which corresponds to about R=20 AU at the distances of the sources. The outer radius of the warm inner region is expected to vary between 20 and 100 AU depending on the source parameters. The largest scale on which the water and H2-18O lines are predicted is at most a couple of hundred AU's, i.e. less than 2 arcseconds, whereas the largest recoverable scale is 4 arcseconds at these frequencies, therefore no compact array is needed and spatial filtering is not an issue.

In this science goal, we will observe the 3(1,2)-2(2,1) and 2(1,1)-2(1,2) HDO transitions (225.9 and 241.6 GHz, Band 6). The peak line strengths were predicted by line radiative transfer modeling of the 1-D physical model of Ced 110 IRS4 by Kristensen et al. (2012). The relative H2O abundance was taken to be 2E-04 in the inner warm (T>100 K) region and several orders of magnitude lower (~1E-08) in the outer parts. The HDO/H2O ratio was assumed to be 3E-4, comparable to what is seen in Earth's Oceans, and lower than found in Class 0 protostars and comets. While the peak flux was estimated with abundances derived in studies of Class~0 sources (i.e. 2E-04), the RMS was estimated from the same model, but assuming a conservative relative water abundance of 2E-05, thus even at this lower value the lines will be detected at a 3 sigma level for 1 km/s bins. Included in the setting is the J=2-1 line of C17O at 224.7 GHz that can put additional constraints on the kinematics. The continuum for the sources were estimated from Henning et al. (1993) by assuming that the emission is evenly distributed over the region and a beam of 0.3 arcseconds. We will target the sources with a spectral resolution of ~0.08 km/s and smooth the data if necessary to improve the signal-to-noise, and as mentioned above the lines will be detected even for a conservative estimate of the water abundance.
To map any spatial differences we need a resolution of 0.3 arcseconds attainable in Band 6 with C34-5, which corresponds to about R=20 AU at the distances of the sources. The outer radius of the warm inner region is expected to vary between 20 and 100 AU depending on the source parameters. The largest scale on which the water and HDO lines are predicted is at most a couple of hundred AU's, i.e. less than 2 arcseconds, whereas the largest recoverable scale is 6.3 arcseconds at these frequencies, therefore no compact array is needed and spatial filtering is not an issue. While these sources have Declinations of -77 degrees, shadowing is not a problem. It is estimated that for the more compact configuration C34-2 the shadowing is at most 10 per-cent at -77 degrees Declination, with the more extended configuration this is even less of an issue. For the same reason the beam will be slightly elliptical, but this is not significant enough to hamper our science goals.

In this science goal, we will observe the 4(1,4)-3(2,1) ortho-H218O transition at 390.6~GHz (Band~8). The peak line strengths were predicted by line radiative transfer modeling of the 1-D physical model of Ced 110 IRS4 by Kristensen et al. (2012). The relative H2O abundance (o/p=3,16O/18O=550) was taken to be 2E-04 in the inner warm (T>100 K) region and several orders of magnitude lower (~1E-08) in the outer parts. While the peak flux was estimated with abundances derived in studies of Class~0 sources (i.e. 2E-04), the RMS was estimated assuming a conservative relative water abundance of 2E-05, thus even at this lower value the lines will be detected at a 3 sigma level for 1 km/s bins. The continuum for the sources were estimated from Henning et al. (1993) by assuming that the emission is evenly distributed over the region and a beam of 0.3 arcseconds. We will target the sources with a spectral resolution of ~0.09 km/s and smooth the data if necessary to improve the signal-to-noise, and as mentioned above the lines will be detected even for a conservative estimate of the water abundance.
To map any spatial differences we need a resolution of 0.3 arcseconds attainable in Band 6 with C34-5, which corresponds to about R=20 AU at the distances of the sources. The outer radius of the warm inner region is expected to vary between 20 and 100 AU depending on the source parameters. The largest scale on which the water and HDO lines are predicted is at most a couple of hundred AU's, i.e. less than 2 arcseconds, whereas the largest recoverable scale is 4 arcseconds at these frequencies, therefore no compact array is needed and spatial filtering is not an issue. While these sources have Declinations of -77 degrees, shadowing is not a problem. It is estimated that for the more compact configuration C34-2 the shadowing is at most 10 per-cent at -77 degrees Declination, with the more extended configuration this is even less of an issue. For the same reason the beam will be slightly elliptical, but this is not significant enough to hamper our science goals.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Water plays an important role throughout the entire star formation process, from cores to disks. In the cold dense outer parts of the protostellar envelope, water is the main constituent of the icy grain mantles. When the grains are heated above 100 K, water is released into the gas phase. Previously, we successfully observed warm water towards four deeply-embedded (Class 0) low-mass protostars. The observations show compact, narrow warm water lines on scales <100 AU, but its origin remains elusive (hot core, disks, or shocks). To determine the location of the warm water emission, we propose to observe the two isotopologues HDO and H2-18O in band 6 and 8 towards four sources that are more evolved (Class I) to further investigate and constrain the origin of the warm water emission and how this is affected by the evolution of the protostellar system. The observations will be able to, for the first time, constrain the location and abundance of warm water vapor in these objects.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Astronomy Department, Michigan at Ann Arbor, University of
